January 13.name: Lohri
January 13.description: Lohri is a popular winter Punjabi folk festival, celebrated primarily in the Indian subcontinent.
January 13.history: Lohri is traditionally associated with the harvest of the rabi crops and is celebrated to mark the end of winter.
January 13.howToCelebrate: People gather around a bonfire, throw in sesame seeds, jaggery, and popcorn, and sing and dance to folk songs.

January 14.name: Makar Sankranti
January 14.description: Makar Sankranti is a Hindu festival dedicated to the sun god Surya. It marks the sun's transition into Capricorn (Makar) and the end of the winter solstice.
January 14.history: The festival has ancient origins and is mentioned in various Hindu scriptures. It signifies the start of longer days.
January 14.howToCelebrate: People take holy dips in rivers, fly kites, prepare sweets made of sesame seeds and jaggery, and donate to the needy.

January 26.name: Republic Day
January 26.description: Republic Day is a national holiday in India that commemorates the adoption of the Constitution of India on 26 January 1950.
January 26.history: The Constitution of India was adopted on this day in 1950, making India a republic. It is one of three national holidays in India.
January 26.howToCelebrate: A grand parade is held in New Delhi, with various state and cultural performances, followed by the president's address to the nation.

February 14.name: Basant Panchami
February 14.description: Basant Panchami is a Hindu festival celebrating Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge, music, and arts.
February 14.history: The festival marks the onset of spring and is celebrated across India, especially in educational institutions.
February 14.howToCelebrate: People wear yellow clothes, offer prayers to Saraswati, and participate in kite flying.

February 24.name: Ravidas Jayanti
February 24.description: Ravidas Jayanti celebrates the birth of the Indian saint and poet Ravidas, who is revered as a spiritual leader in North India.
February 24.history: Ravidas Jayanti is celebrated on the full moon day in the month of Magh, and it marks the birth anniversary of Sant Ravidas.
February 24.howToCelebrate: Devotees gather at Ravidas temples, offer prayers, and read his hymns and teachings.

March 8.name: Maha Shivratri
March 8.description: Maha Shivratri is a Hindu festival dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is a major festival marked by fasting and night-long vigils.
March 8.history: Maha Shivratri is celebrated annually to honor Lord Shiva. It is believed that on this day, Shiva performed the Tandava, the cosmic dance of destruction.
March 8.howToCelebrate: Devotees observe fasting, perform night-long vigils, and offer milk and bel leaves to Shiva's idols.

March 24.name: Holi
March 24.description: Holi, also known as the Festival of Colors, is a Hindu spring festival celebrated across India and Nepal.
March 24.history: Holi has ancient origins and celebrates the victory of good over evil, particularly the burning of Holika, the demoness.
March 24.howToCelebrate: People throw colored powders at each other, dance, sing, and celebrate with festive foods and drinks.

March 25.name: Dhulendi
March 25.description: Dhulendi, also known as Holi, is celebrated the day after Holika Dahan. It's the day when people play with colors.
March 25.history: Dhulendi follows the day of Holika Dahan and is the main day of Holi when people splash colors on each other.
March 25.howToCelebrate: People gather in open spaces, splash colors, and celebrate with music, dance, and sweets.

April 11.name: Id-ul-Fitr
April 11.description: Id-ul-Fitr, also known as Eid, is an Islamic festival that marks the end of Ramadan, the holy month of fasting.
April 11.history: Eid has been celebrated by Muslims worldwide since the time of the Prophet Muhammad. It is a day of thanksgiving and charity.
April 11.howToCelebrate: Muslims attend special prayers, give Zakat (charity), and share festive meals with family and friends.

April 13.name: Baisakhi
April 13.description: Baisakhi is a festival celebrated mainly in Punjab and Haryana, marking the start of the harvest season.
April 13.history: Baisakhi also commemorates the formation of the Khalsa in 1699 by Guru Gobind Singh. It is a major Sikh festival.
April 13.howToCelebrate: People visit gurdwaras, perform traditional dances like bhangra, and celebrate with feasts.

April 14.name: Ambedkar Jayanti
April 14.description: Ambedkar Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, the principal architect of the Indian Constitution.
April 14.history: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was born on 14 April 1891. He is remembered for his contributions to social justice and the Indian Constitution.
April 14.howToCelebrate: People pay tribute to Ambedkar by visiting his memorials, participating in cultural events, and holding discussions on his works.

April 17.name: Ram Navami
April 17.description: Ram Navami is a Hindu festival celebrating the birth of Lord Rama, the seventh avatar of Vishnu.
April 17.history: Ram Navami is celebrated as the birthday of Lord Rama, who is believed to have been born on this day in Ayodhya.
April 17.howToCelebrate: Devotees read the Ramayana, participate in processions, and offer prayers at temples.

April 21.name: Mahavir Jayanti
April 21.description: Mahavir Jayanti is a Jain festival celebrating the birth of Lord Mahavir, the 24th Tirthankara.
April 21.history: Lord Mahavir was born in 599 BCE in Bihar, India. His teachings form the foundation of Jainism.
April 21.howToCelebrate: Jains visit temples, meditate, and listen to teachings about Lord Mahavir's life.

May 23.name: Budh Purnima
May 23.description: Budh Purnima, also known as Buddha Jayanti, celebrates the birth, enlightenment, and death of Gautama Buddha.
May 23.history: Budh Purnima is celebrated on the full moon day in the Hindu month of Vaisakha. It commemorates the three major events in Buddha's life.
May 23.howToCelebrate: Buddhists visit temples, offer prayers, meditate, and share Buddha's teachings.

June 17.name: Id-ul-Zuha
June 17.description: Id-ul-Zuha, also known as Eid al-Adha or Bakrid, is an Islamic festival of sacrifice, commemorating Ibrahim's willingness to sacrifice his son.
June 17.history: Eid al-Adha honors Ibrahim's (Abraham's) obedience to God. It is celebrated after the annual Hajj pilgrimage.
June 17.howToCelebrate: Muslims perform prayers, sacrifice an animal, and distribute the meat among family, friends, and the poor.

July 17.name: Muharram
July 17.description: Muharram is the first month of the Islamic calendar and is observed as a period of mourning and reflection by Shia Muslims.
July 17.history: Muharram is observed in memory of the martyrdom of Imam Hussain, the grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, at the Battle of Karbala.
July 17.howToCelebrate: Shia Muslims observe fasts, participate in processions, and engage in mourning rituals.

August 15.name: Independence Day
August 15.description: Independence Day celebrates India's freedom from British rule on August 15, 1947.
August 15.history: India gained independence from British rule on August 15, 1947. It is a national holiday and is celebrated with flag hoisting and cultural events.
August 15.howToCelebrate: The Prime Minister hoists the national flag at the Red Fort in Delhi, followed by a speech and cultural performances across the country.

August 19.name: Janmashtami
August 19.description: Janmashtami is a Hindu festival celebrating the birth of Lord Krishna, the eighth avatar of Vishnu.
August 19.history: Janmashtami is observed on the eighth day of the dark fortnight in the month of Bhadrapada and marks Krishna's birth in Mathura.
August 19.howToCelebrate: Devotees fast, sing devotional songs, and reenact episodes from Krishna's life, especially the Raas Leela.

September 17.name: Ganesh Chaturthi
September 17.description: Ganesh Chaturthi is a Hindu festival celebrating the birth of Lord Ganesha, the elephant-headed god of wisdom and prosperity.
September 17.history: Ganesh Chaturthi is celebrated with grand enthusiasm, especially in Maharashtra, and marks the beginning of the festival of Ganesha's birth.
September 17.howToCelebrate: People set up Ganesh idols, perform prayers, sing devotional songs, and organize processions for immersion.

October 2.name: Gandhi Jayanti
October 2.description: Gandhi Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi, the leader of India's non-violent independence movement.
October 2.history: Mahatma Gandhi was born on October 2, 1869. The day is observed as the International Day of Non-Violence.
October 2.howToCelebrate: People attend commemorative events, participate in community service, and reflect on Gandhi's principles of peace and non-violence.

October 24.name: Diwali
October 24.description: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is the Hindu festival of lights celebrating the victory of light over darkness and good over evil.
October 24.history: Diwali is a major Hindu festival celebrated over five days, commemorating the return of Lord Rama to Ayodhya after defeating Ravana.
October 24.howToCelebrate: People light oil lamps, burst crackers, exchange sweets, and participate in pujas dedicated to Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth.

November 1.name: All Saints Day
November 1.description: All Saints Day is a Christian holiday honoring all saints, known and unknown, who have attained heaven.
November 1.history: All Saints Day is celebrated on November 1st and is dedicated to saints who are not specifically honored on other days.
November 1.howToCelebrate: Christians attend church services, light candles in memory of saints, and reflect on the lives of holy figures.

November 15.name: Guru Nanak Jayanti
November 15.description: Guru Nanak Jayanti, also known as Gurpurab, celebrates the birth of Guru Nanak, the founder of Sikhism.
November 15.history: Guru Nanak was born on 15 November 1469. His teachings form the basis of Sikhism and emphasize equality and devotion to God.
November 15.howToCelebrate: Sikhs attend Gurdwara services, sing hymns, and participate in processions.

November 23.name: Chhath Puja
November 23.description: Chhath Puja is a Hindu festival dedicated to the Sun God and is primarily celebrated in Bihar, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.
November 23.history: The festival is observed over four days and involves rituals to thank the Sun God for sustaining life on Earth.
November 23.howToCelebrate: Devotees fast, offer prayers, and perform rituals on riverbanks or water bodies during sunrise and sunset.

December 25.name: Christmas
December 25.description: Christmas is a Christian festival celebrating the birth of Jesus Christ.
December 25.history: Christmas is observed on December 25th and marks the birth of Jesus, who is considered the Son of God in Christianity.
December 25.howToCelebrate: Christians attend church services, decorate homes with Christmas trees, exchange gifts, and enjoy festive meals.
